headline: CNN Newsroom
subHeadline: Israel Defense Forces Fires Two Over Strikes That Killed Aid Workers; U.S. Preparing For Significant Attack By Iran On U.S. Or Israeli Assets; Ecuadorian Police Forcibly Entered Mexico's Embassy; Taiwan Earthquake Death Toll Rises To 13; Total Eclipse Of The Sun On Monday. Aired 4-4:30a ET

utterances.speaker: ANNA COREN, CNN ANCHOR AND CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Welcome to all of you watching from around the world. I'm Anna Coren, live from Hong Kong.Ahead on CNN NEWSROOM, Israel's preliminary investigation into the death of seven aid workers in Gaza finds internal failure is in the chain of command. What world leaders are calling for as Israel deals with the fallout. And Russia launched a new series of missile strikes in Eastern Ukraine. Now one aid group says its office in Donetsk is destroyed. Plus diplomacy between Ecuador and Mexico is breaking down following a police raid on the Mexican embassy in Quito just hours ago. What we know about the situation right now. (MUSIC PLAYING)

utterances.speaker: COREN
utterances.sentences: The charity World Central Kitchen is reacting to Israel's investigation into the drone strike that killed seven of its aid workers. In a report released on Friday, Israel admitted its own decision-making procedures were violated and fired two of the officers involved.The deaths of the aid workers prompted the charity to withdraw from Gaza for the time being. After the IDF report was released, World Central Kitchen said in a statement, quote, "We demand the creation of an independent commission to investigate the killings of our WCK colleagues. The IDF cannot credibly investigate its own failure in Gaza." The head of one group, a former CNN correspondent, Arwa Damon, told us that the strike has shocked her and other aid workers. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ARWA DAMON, FOUNDER AND PRESIDENT, INARA
utterances.sentences: It was very unnerving and it's really jarring to be on the ground as a humanitarian, wanting to go and provide assistance and food and medicine all sorts of other things that the population here just because they (INAUDIBLE).And to have that in the pit of your stomach of, am I going to be targeted? (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COREN
utterances.sentences: In the wake of the aid workers' deaths, Israel says it's opening a new crossing to allow more aid into Gaza. It also plans to allow aid to go through the Israeli port of Ashdod.Well, Norway's top diplomat believes the report hardly makes Israel look good. He attended a NATO meeting on Thursday, when the alliance marked its 75th anniversary. The minister said the report only shows how easy it is for Israel to open fire when it suspects someone is a terrorist, even when evidence is weak. And he said NATO countries are starting to lose patience with Israel. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ESPEN BARTH EIDE, NORWEGIAN FOREIGN MINISTER
utterances.sentences: Yesterday I was together with most of my Western foreign minister colleague at the NATO meeting in Brussels. And I could really feel that the frustration, even among those who have been most supportive of Israel until now is that this is really going too far.So something is moving here when it comes to not whether Israel has the right to defend itself, which it has but they have been doing it for almost six months now. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COREN
utterances.sentences: CNN's Nada Bashir joins us now from London with more.Nada, there is this growing international pressure on Israel to allow an independent investigation into the killing of these humanitarian aid workers, from the families and from governments. Is this likely to happen?

utterances.speaker: BASHIR
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. The U.S. has issued a warning to Iran, according to officials, not to target U.S. military bases. We heard yesterday saying that the Israeli strike in Damascus should not be used as a pretext to attack U.S. personnel and facilities.That according to a U.S. State Department spokesperson. The warning, of course, sent in response to a warning from Iran for the U.S. not to be pulled into further and deeper into the conflict with Israel. But of course, there is mounting concern around the situation across the region as we continue to see these incidences and attacks. There are fears that this could trigger and provoke a further escalation beyond the region. We have seen this, of course, sometimes before, particularly early in the year across the southern border of Lebanon. But certainly mounting concern now that this could lead to an escalation if this is not defused.

utterances.speaker: COREN
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile Hezbollah says that Israel's strike in Syria on Monday was a new milestone and that the expected Iranian response will mark an entirely new phase in the Middle East.Israel struck Iran's consulate building in Damascus, killing top Iranian commanders. Hezbollah leaders spoke about the strike on Friday when the group marked what it calls Jerusalem Day in Lebanon. CNN's Ben Wedeman has more from Beirut. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) BEN WEDEMAN, CNN SENIOR INTERNATIONAL CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Hezbollah's marching band kicks off an event in Beirut marking Yom al- Quds -- or Jerusalem Day -- a day set aside by Iran's Ayatollah Khomeini 45 years ago in support of the Palestinian cause. And while the masked Hezbollah fighters carried the Palestinian flag, when Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah addressed the crowd, the focus was last Monday's Israeli bombing in Syria that killed, among others, two senior commanders of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps.

utterances.speaker: WEDEMAN
utterances.sentences: In a speech, Hassan Nasrallah said the response to the Israeli strike on the Iranian consulate in Damascus Monday is coming. He said it is inevitable, he made it clear, that response would be Iranian (ph).ROBERTSON (voice-over): And the details of that response, he said, are Iran's concern. Where, how, when, the scope, said Nasrallah, well, that's not our business to ask about or interfere in. That's up to the supreme leader. If Iran strikes back, it would be the first time since the Gaza war erupted that Iran steps out from behind its allies and proxies and attacks Israel directly. For months, Hezbollah, closely aligned with Iran, has been trading fire across the border with Israel. An Iranian strike on Israel would circumvent the middle militia. In Tehran, Iran's supreme leader, Ali Khamenei, paid final respects to the Iranians killed in Damascus. He has vowed revenge. Tens of thousands paraded Friday through the Iranian capital for Jerusalem Day. It's an annual event where the chants and symbols are predictable, as Israel and Iran risk careening from strike to counter- strike to full-blown confrontation. -- Ben Wedeman, CNN, Beirut. (END VIDEOTAPE) (MUSIC PLAYING)

utterances.speaker: COREN
utterances.sentences: The U.S. Treasury Secretary announced new talks with China focused on balanced economic growth between the two nations. Janet Yellen is in China right now as part of her second visit to the country with the Biden administration. She met with the Chinese vice premier in Guangzhou earlier.Yellen says the new initiatives will advance the interests of American workers and firms. The Treasury Secretary also raised U.S. concerns about China's trade with Russia. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) JANET YELLEN, U.S. TREASURY SECRETARY: China has emphasized that it is their policy not to provide Russia with military support, that neither of us want this to be an issue in our bilateral relationship. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COREN
utterances.sentences: Well, Yellen says she spent two hours discussing the issue of China's production overcapacity with the vice premier on Saturday. The Treasury Secretary says she believes Beijing understood this as an important issue for the U.S.Just ahead, Mother Nature may throw a curve ball ahead of Monday's total solar eclipse. The last forecast coming up. (MUSIC PLAYING) (COMMERCIAL BREAK) (MUSIC PLAYING)

utterances.speaker: COREN
utterances.sentences: As eclipse chasers are crowding into the path of totality for Monday's total solar eclipse, one small Texas town is rolling out the welcome mat, grilling meat, playing music and selling plenty of merchandise.And though the weather forecasts may be dicey, the crowds are coming, clouds or not. CNN's Rosa Flores takes us to the town of Bandera. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Welcome to Bandera, you guys.ROSA FLORES, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): It's the cowboy capital of the world.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Lots of Western bands and good dancing.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: Bandera, Texas, is in the path of totality for Monday's solar eclipse. The town is expected to experience more than four minutes of darkness.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Rosa, I know you're over there but I can't see you.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: I can't see you.Eclipse-mania has taken hold of Bandera. Horses and dinosaurs are donning eclipse glasses. Even eyewear for a giant cowboy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: One monster eclipse party.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We are downtown Bandera, Texas. Behind this here is the courthouse.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: Bandera's population of under 1,000 --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Everybody knows everybody.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: -- it is expected to quadruple Monday, says the mayor.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: At 11th Street cowboy bar, the meat --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Medium rare.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: -- and greet is about the eclipse.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We drove 1,700 miles.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: Seventeen hundred miles to see the eclipse?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: These two friends caravan from Pennsylvania.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I've been preparing. I bought a camper. I bought a Jeep. I did everything.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: You bought a camper for the eclipse?I hear that it might storm in Bandera.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No, it's going to be a beautiful day.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: Are we doing positive thinking about this?Positive thinking. It's not just Bandera's cowgirls praying for good weather. Millions are expected to flock to Texas and more than a dozen U.S. states in the celestial path of totality. Some officials are worried about traffic jams. And who's this? UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: This is Wooster.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: In Bandera, cowgirls solved that problem

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I'm going to jump on Wooster and I'm going to ride by everybody. And I do my little princess wave even.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: Eclipse mania expected to add $6 billion to the U.S. economy in one estimate. Texas, a slice of the astronomical pie, $1.4 billion. The eclipse merchandise in Bandera --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: They sold like that.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: -- is practically sold out.Well, this is beautiful country, Alec,

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: So are venues like the historic Dixie Dude Ranch.And when did you start getting calls about the eclipse?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Our first reservation for the eclipse was in 2017. I think we sold out completely about four years ago.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: What never runs out here are the good people --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: And a Moon Pie.

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: Moon Pie?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It's the eclipse.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: FLORES
utterances.sentences: For the eclipse. Thank you.And the good times. Some of those good times in Bandera happen on a horse. There are thousands of people who are expected to be here for the big day on Monday. And a lot of people are worried about the weather. They're worried about cloud cover. Not here Monday or they're going to have a good time anyway -- Rosa Flores, CNN, Bandera, Texas. (END VIDEOTAPE)
